channel.title: Some Information on 449
channel.description:
[code]Updating... Runescape Build #449 Attempting use of Primary Hooks. getBytes() added to class "rd" gets field "rd.byte[] R" getPassword() added to class "client" gets static field "ff.rd w" getUsername() added to class "client" gets static field "ff.rd f" getPlayerValids() added to class "client" gets static field "r.int[] R" getPlayers() added to class "client" gets static field "f.td[] Lc" getPlayerCount() added to class "client" gets static field "l.int J" getName() added to class "td" gets field "td.rd Gd" getMessage() added to class "f" gets field "f.rd Qb" getMonsterValids() added to class "client" gets static field "ca.int[] b" getMonsters() added to class "client" gets static field "ta.b[] Nb" getMonsterCount() added to class "client" gets static field "l.int J" getComposite() added to class "b" gets field "b.tb md" getName() added to class "tb" gets field "tb.rd sb" getID() added to class "tb" gets field "tb.int zb" getLevel() added to class "tb" gets field "tb.int Tb" getLevel() added to class "td" gets field "td.int sd" getPlayerMe() added to class "client" gets static field "af.td p" getChatMessages() added to class "client" gets static field "df.rd[] o" getChatTypes() added to class "client" gets static field "df.int[] i" getChatNames() added to class "client" gets static field "wd.rd[] j" Updated in 62ms.[/code]
Yes this is output from my BCEL bot, no this is not my only bot project. This happends to be an overly glorified auto talker... But hey, at least it can tell you your combat level. HAH. Jokes... jokes... anyway, yeah, the only things that really have backup hooks are level for npc and player, the 3 chat arrays, username, password, and lastly stringwrapper. BCEL has a few issues that need to be worked out, so I'm unsure of how much more I'm going to add to the BCEL version of the bot.

item.title: Some Information on 449
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:40, topic:60247”][quote author=semaphore link=topic=86752.msg935609#msg935609 date=1172305651]
Speed is completely secondary. In production, who the hell is there to care if your update happened in 8 seconds or 8 picoseconds?

My update is slow. I really don’t give a ratfart in space. I’m not there to care if it’s so fast I didn’t get to blink twice. What I do know is that every single one of the bots are running again within a couple minutes of the update… and I didn’t have to be there to hold their hands.
[/quote]

i could be wrong, but i if you do it in less time wouldn’t that make your code more efficient.[/quote]

Efficiency in this case is the ratio of reliability to time. Preliminary tests of my new updater (WIP) suggest that it might reach MINUTES with a lot of hooks if I code the search procedures sloppily. The payoff for taking extra time is that it will be rock solid if everything goes according to plan. I’m assuming most of you are searching for code patterns, and that’s how you’re getting updates in milliseconds. This updater takes a broader view of things, and in consequence should still work even if a few of the patterns break - any given pattern just helps, it’s not critical.

So in this case, the reliability/time ratio will be extremely high - in exchange for (hopefully worst case) a few minutes during which I won’t be running a bot, I get an update system that can take care of itself within reasonable limits. I think that’s valid, since in quite a few key areas the RuneScape client is still like it was in Classic (they’re not changing fundamental design to stop us, just the ‘cosmetics’, so to speak).

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on 449
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:40, topic:60247”][quote author=semaphore link=topic=86752.msg935609#msg935609 date=1172305651]
Speed is completely secondary. In production, who the hell is there to care if your update happened in 8 seconds or 8 picoseconds?

My update is slow. I really don’t give a ratfart in space. I’m not there to care if it’s so fast I didn’t get to blink twice. What I do know is that every single one of the bots are running again within a couple minutes of the update… and I didn’t have to be there to hold their hands.
[/quote]

i could be wrong, but i if you do it in less time wouldn’t that make your code more efficient.[/quote]

Not really, you could see a huge gain in speed by writing everything in the main() method without instantiating any new objects or calling any helper methods, your code would be quick, but ugly and unmanageable as hell. Abstraction is a good thing, use it.

Just as long as you don’t do something extremely stupid with your code it should be fast enough, ie don’t break into recursion to add up a few numbers, don’t search through a huge ass array linearly etc etc. If you are going to focus on speed you only need to worry about the methods/parts that are called the most amount of times, saving 5ms on a procedure you use once isn’t going to help nearly as much as cutting .5ms off of a procedure that iterates through 10000 times.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on 449
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

Efficient code is a novelty

Yea, it is :). Updating speed, doesn’t really matter. Its just…nice to have :). Reliability though, first should be taken into account. No point having a light speed updater when everything is breaking.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on 449
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Efficient code is a novelty. One thing most of you don’t understand yet, because you have not left the nest, is that code written for real-world companies is very inefficient. There are a few shops that have good, clean code. Google is a good example. What you’ll find is that as you mature and gain experience, you will learn the times it is appropriate to sacrifice efficiency for reliability. Most of the situations where you will run into this are when you are crunched for time. If you are a still-living-at-home-working-at-pizza-hut kid, the pedantic clinging to faster code makes sense and sounds about right. Most inexperienced developers will get so hung up on ‘efficiency’ that they will end up not completing a project because they spent too much time trying to ‘look good’… and who do you think has to come along to clean up those messes? I think the same could be said about some people in the community. They get so hung up on ‘speed’ that they end up with little more than a basic system that can update a few menial fields in world-record time but can’t do much more than login, walk around in a circle, and say something over and over. If that is what you’re aiming for, great. (PSB as much as that sounded like it was aimed at you, it really wasn’t… I’ve heard this ‘party-line’ from a few people)

This is not a bash against speed. It’s a bash against the pedantic drive to squeeze every last drop of efficiency from your code. This leads to burn out and eventually leads to never finishing what you started…

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on 449
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

ruler:

Why are you guys so focused on your updating speed but not on your bot speed?

I don’t want to sit there for 20 seconds while a bot updates just to check if my hook works. Especially when you are making one you need to test a lot of things thus the quicker the better.

Updating speed is simply a nice feature. The general bot speed is also very important.

Read full topic

0-16 ms.
